item.title: Roque Dalton - Poetry and Militancy in Latin America
item.description: [Poesía y Militancia en América Latina] 1. What is it I mean to do, working in poetry? In general, to express my life, by which I mean the life to which I’m witness and coauthor. My time, its people, the environment we share, with all its interdependence. I walk towards this goal from the apparently simple starting point of being Salvadoran, which is to say, part of a Latin American people that seeks its happiness fighting against imperialism and the criollo oligarchy that, for well-established historical reasons, has an extraordinarily poor cultural tradition.

item.title: Ernesto Cardenal - Kaianerekowa
item.description: [Kayanerenkowa] Sept. Oct. in these months are the migrations. The tanagers of Ohio the kingbirds of Oklahoma and Texas come to Nicaragua. The cormorant comes from Michigan to Solentiname here they call him the pato-e-chancho. Yes, like the planes. The plane from New York above these solitudes. Maybe watching a color movie. THE PERFECT FURLOUGH ***with Tony Curtis and Janet Leigh*** above Solentiname. And flying in a V come the Canadian ducks

item.title: Roberto Fernández Retamar - Stranger, Stranger Still
item.description: [Extraño, Más Extraño] In the dark I touch America’s scar I lay my burning hand on the volcanic and humid South from where we came bleeding alongside other tears. This severe beauty is the eye of my land, and its shadow of fire shakes me. Stay here, bare, don’t leave. Deserted, drunk I shiver in a strange country, stranger still.

item.title: Ernesto Cardenal - Midnight Office
item.description: [Oficio Nocturno] 2 AM. It is the hour of the Midnight Office, and in shadow the church seems full of demons. This is the hour of darkness and parties. The hour of my binges. And my past returns. “And my sin is always before me” And while we recite the psalms, my memories interfere with prayer like radios and jukeboxes. Old movie scenes come back, nightmares, hours alone in hotels, dances, journeys, kisses, bars.
